text: What's taught now in business schools generally sucks. People aren't prepared educationally, and they sure don't get prepared for it in companies. It's intellectually challenging and it's emotionally intimidating.
speaker: Roger Martin
context: Lenny asks Roger why so many people are bad at strategy. Roger explains that there are multiple reasons why strategy is difficult for most people. He identifies that business schools have moved away from teaching practical strategy and instead focus on theoretical approaches that don't work in the real world. Companies also don't provide good strategic training, leaving people unprepared for the intellectual and emotional challenges that strategy work requires.
text_ko: 지금 경영대학원(business schools)에서 가르치는 건 대체로 형편없어요. 사람들은 교육적으로 준비가 안 돼 있고, 회사에서도 전혀 준비시켜 주지 않아요. 그건 지적으로는 도전적이고 정서적으로는 위압적이에요.
text_zh: 现在商学院教的那些东西基本上都不怎么样。学生在学校里没学到什么真本事，进了公司也得不到什么像样的培训。这活儿既烧脑又让人压力山大。
text_es: Lo que enseñan ahora en las escuelas de negocios es bastante malo. La gente no viene preparada desde la educación, y desde luego tampoco los preparan en las empresas. Es un desafío intelectual enorme y emocionalmente te puede intimidar muchísimo.

text: Strategy is an integrated set of choices that compels desired customer action. So, the way I think about it is, there's a whole bunch of things a company controls, how many factories to build, how much R&D to do, in what areas, and how much advertising to do, how many people to hire, what to pay them, blah, blah, blah... Those are all the things under our control.
speaker: Roger Martin
context: Lenny asks Roger to define what strategy actually is. Roger provides his core definition of strategy and explains the fundamental challenge - companies can control their internal decisions like factories, R&D spending, and hiring, but they cannot control what customers ultimately choose to do. Strategy is therefore about making the right internal choices to influence customer behavior in your favor.
text_ko: 전략(strategy)은 원하는 고객 행동을 이끌어내는 선택들의 통합된 집합이에요. 제가 보는 관점은, 회사가 통제할 수 있는 것들이 아주 많다는 거예요 — 공장을 몇 개 지을지, 연구개발(R&D)을 얼마나 할지 어느 분야에 투자할지, 광고(advertising)를 얼마나 할지, 몇 명을 채용할지, 임금을 얼마로 책정할지, 뭐 이런저런… 이 모든 게 우리가 통제할 수 있는 것들이에요.
text_zh: 战略就是一套完整的选择组合，能够推动客户按我们希望的方式行动。我是这么理解的，公司能控制的东西有一大堆，比如建多少工厂，研发投入多少钱、投在哪些领域，广告预算怎么分配，招多少人，给多少薪水，等等等等...这些都是我们能掌控的。
text_es: La estrategia es un conjunto integrado de decisiones que impulsa a los clientes a hacer lo que queremos. O sea, como yo lo veo, hay un montón de cosas que la empresa puede controlar: cuántas plantas construir, cuánto invertir en I+D (R&D), en qué áreas, cuánta publicidad hacer, a cuánta gente contratar, cuánto pagarles, y así sucesivamente... Todas esas son cosas que están bajo nuestro control.

text: You have to be either differentiated or low cost, there's no way to protect yourself if you're not one of those two. It's literally like having a bully who can just shove you, and you take one step back, then they shove you, and you take another step back, and they shove you, and you take another step back.
speaker: Roger Martin
context: Lenny asks about the two routes to winning that Roger describes - being the lowest cost option or being differentiated. Roger emphasizes that these are the only two viable competitive positions, referencing Michael Porter's foundational strategy work. He uses a vivid analogy to explain what happens to companies that get stuck in the middle - they become vulnerable to competitors who can push them around at will because they have no defensible position.
text_ko: 차별화(differentiated)되거나 저비용(low cost)이어야 해요. 그 둘 중 하나가 아니면 자신을 보호할 방법이 전혀 없어요. 말 그대로 괴롭히는 상대가 계속 밀어붙이는 것과 같아요. 한 번 밀면 한 발 물러서고, 또 밀면 또 한 발 물러서고, 그렇게 계속 밀려요.
text_zh: 你必须要么有差异化，要么成本够低，如果这两样你都不占，那就没法保护自己。这就像遇到一个恶霸，他推你一下，你就往后退一步，他再推你，你又退一步，他接着推，你还是只能继续往后退。
text_es: Tienes que ser diferente o ser el más barato, no hay otra forma de protegerte si no eres una de estas dos cosas. Es literalmente como tener un matón que te empuja, y tú das un paso atrás, luego te empuja otra vez, y das otro paso atrás, y te vuelve a empujar, y sigues retrocediendo.

text: You'll know you're playing to play if you're not aiming to, and accomplishing, having either an offer where Lenny walks into the store, whatever kind of store it is, and says to the person in the store, I want that brand. An example, Lego, one of the companies I've worked with for a long time, great company.
speaker: Roger Martin
context: Lenny asks how to recognize if you're just "playing to play" rather than "playing to win" in your strategy. Roger explains that customers provide the clearest signal - if customers specifically request your brand by name rather than seeing you as interchangeable with competitors, you're truly winning. He uses Lego as an example of a brand that has achieved this level of customer preference and loyalty.
text_ko: 당신이 플레이 투 플레이(playing to play)를 하고 있는지 아는 방법은, Lenny가 아무 가게에 들어가서 점원한테 "저 브랜드 갖고 싶어요"라고 말하게 만드는 오퍼(offer)를 목표로 삼지도 않고, 또 실제로 만들어내지도 못하고 있을 때예요. 예로 제가 오랫동안 함께 일해온 훌륭한 회사인 레고(Lego)가 있어요.
text_zh: 你就知道自己是在瞎折腾，如果你做不到这一点的话——就是让任何一个顾客，比如说Lenny，走进店里，不管是什么店，然后跟店员说"我就要那个牌子的"。举个例子，乐高，我合作了很久的一家公司，非常棒的企业。
text_es: Sabrás que estás jugando por jugar si no te estás enfocando en lograr que tu oferta sea tan fuerte que Lenny entre a la tienda, del tipo que sea, y le diga al vendedor "quiero esa marca". Un ejemplo perfecto es Lego, una de las empresas con las que he trabajado por mucho tiempo, excelente compañía.

text: I have never met this mythical beast called a great natural strategist. Great strategists have all one thing in common, they just practice. And anybody, there's no such thing as a person who is willing to practice strategy, who will end up saying, I'm operational, I don't do strategy well.
speaker: Roger Martin
context: As Roger wraps up the conversation, Lenny asks if there's any final advice he'd like to share. Roger addresses a common misconception that some people are just naturally gifted at strategy while others aren't. He argues that strategic thinking is a learned skill that improves with practice, not an innate talent. He encourages listeners to start practicing strategic thinking rather than waiting or assuming they're not cut out for it.
text_ko: 저는 '타고난 전략가(natural strategist)'라는 전설 같은 존재를 한 번도 만나본 적이 없어요. 위대한 전략가들에게는 공통점이 하나 있는데, 그냥 연습을 한다는 거예요. 그리고 누구든 전략(strategy)을 기꺼이 연습하는 사람이라면 결국 '나는 오퍼레이션(operational)만 해요, 전략은 잘 못해요'라고 말하게 되는 일은 없어요.
text_zh: 我从来没见过什么天生的战略大师这种神话般的存在。真正厉害的战略家都有一个共同点，就是不断练习。任何人，只要愿意花时间练战略思维，绝对不会最后还说"我只会做执行，战略我搞不好"。
text_es: Nunca me he topado con esa criatura mítica que llaman "el gran estratega nato". Los grandes estrategas tienen una cosa en común: simplemente practican. Y cualquier persona, no existe alguien que esté dispuesto a practicar estrategia que termine diciendo "soy operativo, no se me da bien la estrategia".

text: I just think of it as a problem solving tool. And what problem should you attempt to solve? You should attempt to solve something where your current outcomes that you're getting are lower than the outcomes you wish you were getting. That's what I call a gap.
speaker: Roger Martin
context: Lenny asks Roger for a tactical approach to help people who feel overwhelmed by strategy work. Roger introduces his concept of "betterment over perfection" as a practical starting point. Instead of trying to solve everything at once, he recommends identifying the most painful gap between current performance and desired outcomes, then using strategic thinking to close that specific gap before moving to the next one.
vocabulary_highlights: That's what I call a gap
text_ko: 저는 그걸 그냥 문제 해결 도구(problem solving tool)로 생각해요. 어떤 문제를 풀어야 하냐고요? 바로 지금 얻고 있는 결과가 원하던 성과만큼 나오지 않을 때 그 문제를 풀어야 해요. 저는 그걸 격차(gap)라고 불러요.
text_zh: 我觉得这就是个解决问题的工具嘛。那应该解决什么问题呢？你应该去解决那种现状跟你期望的结果之间有差距的问题。我把这个叫做缺口(gap)。
text_es: Yo simplemente lo veo como una herramienta para resolver problemas. ¿Y qué problema deberías intentar resolver? Deberías enfocarte en algo donde los resultados que estás obteniendo ahora están por debajo de los resultados que te gustaría tener. A eso yo le llamo una brecha (gap).
